title: Space salads and salty waters
summary: The two winning proposals in the 2023 round of STEP grants are a project that will study growing edible plants in simulated deep-space exploration conditions, and a project will study salty lakes on Earth that share characteristics with the oceans of other planets and moons.

title: Way out there
summary: We’re always learning more about the worlds of the outer Solar System, and even those beyond.

title: Vulcan: Preview of the Flight Readiness Firing
Five asteroid deflection techniques to save the Earth
summary: Kinetic impactor or nuclear blast? Here are some ways to defend our planet from a dangerous asteroid.

title: Moon-spying missions and a planetary evil twin
summary: Whether they’re dedicated to it or not, planetary missions can get beautiful and informative glimpses at distant moons. And who’s the evil twin: Venus or Earth?

title: Hypersonic Missiles are Just Misunderstood
summary: By Tory BrunoIt’s hard to go anywhere without hearing about the new threat of hypersonic missiles. China and Russia have them, the United States does not! Even the news has been breathlessly announcing that “Russia used hypersonic missiles against Uk...

title: Why is Venus called Earth’s twin?
summary: Although Venus and Earth have many differences, they're often called twins because of some key similarities. Looking back to the two planets' early history, the similarities run even deeper.

title: Hard-working spacecraft and even harder-working microbes
summary: The Soyuz spacecraft have been helping humans get to and from space for decades, but that’s nothing compared to the billions of years that microorganisms have been making life on Earth possible.

title: Why has SpaceX's Starship sparked an environmental controversy?
summary: An interview with environmental policy expert Eric Roesch about what made the April 2023 Starship test launch so environmentally harmful, and why the Federal Aviation Administration may ultimately be to blame.

title: How did Earth get its oxygen?
summary: A tiny, Sun-loving microbe has made a very big impact on our atmosphere.
